title: How do you teach empathy? - Jonathan Juravich

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's childhood experience that taught them about empathy?

options.text: Spending time with their blind grandmother

multiple-choice.question: How did the speaker's grandmother encourage them to develop empathy?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking them to describe the physical environment

options.label: B
options.text: By asking them to explain the plot of a movie

options.label: C
options.text: By asking them to "tell me about your stories"

options.label: D
options.text: By asking them to help with household chores

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker believe is the root of empathy?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By asking her to explain why she feels a certain way

options.label: C
options.text: By asking her to talk about a time when she was proud

options.label: B
options.text: They wrote letters to the people affected

options.label: C
options.text: They created a 5-foot tall house structure with polka dots

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: A donation to a health organization

options.label: C
options.text: An art supply donated to a school in Houston

options.label: D
options.text: A letter written to a victim of the hurricane

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The world's ugliest animal

multiple-choice.question: What is the blobfish commonly referred to as?

options.text: In the ocean off the coast of North America

options.label: B
options.text: In the ocean off the coast of Australia

multiple-choice.question: At what depth does the blobfish typically live?

options.label: A
options.text: Near the surface of the ocean

options.label: B
options.text: About 5 times deeper than most ocean animals

options.label: C
options.text: Almost at the sea floor, nearly 10 times deeper than most ocean animals

options.label: D
options.text: In the middle of the ocean

options.label: A
options.text: Warm and sunny with low pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Pitch-black, near-freezing, and extremely high pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Its gooey, jelly-like body can handle the squeezing from the pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Its streamlined body allows it to swim quickly away from the pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Its large size helps to distribute the pressure

options.text: It has a lot of muscle and many bones

options.label: B
options.text: It has almost no muscle and very few bones

options.label: C
options.text: It has a mix of muscle and bones similar to other fish

multiple-choice.question: How does the blobfish's buoyancy help it?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the blobfish to swim quickly and efficiently

options.label: B
options.text: It enables the blobfish to float comfortably above the ocean floor without using too much energy

options.label: C
options.text: It helps the blobfish to hide from predators

options.label: D
options.text: It allows the blobfish to change color

multiple-choice.question: How does the blobfish typically obtain food?

options.label: A
options.text: By actively hunting and chasing prey

options.label: B
options.text: By using its sharp teeth to catch fish

options.label: C
options.text: By swallowing food that happens to float by

options.label: D
options.text: By filtering small organisms from the water

multiple-choice.question: Why do blobfish often appear more blob-like when caught and brought to the surface?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are stressed and anxious

options.label: B
options.text: Because the pressure at the surface is too low

options.label: C
options.text: Because the pressure at the bottom of the ocean squeezes their body into a more normal shape

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are sick or injured

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message about the blobfish's appearance?

options.label: A

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It is only found in polluted waters

multiple-choice.question: What condition can cause diaphragm muscles to stop contracting, leading to breathing difficulties?
What type of ventilation technique involves pumping air into the patient's lungs through a tube?
What device, developed in 1928, was a portable, metal machine with pumps powered by an electric motor?
Why did hospitals shift towards positive pressure ventilation in the 1960s?

options.label: C
options.text: Because negative pressure designs restricted patient movement and obstructed access for caregivers

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the embedded computer system in modern ventilators?

options.label: A
options.text: To monitor the patient's heart rate

options.label: B
options.text: To adjust the airflow and monitor the patient's breathing

multiple-choice.question: Why are ventilators not used as a standard treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they require heavy sedation and can cause long-term lung damage

multiple-choice.question: What is a major limitation of current ventilator models?

options.label: B
options.text: They are too expensive and require extensive training to operate

multiple-choice.question: Why is there an urgent need for more low-cost and portable ventilators?

options.label: A
options.text: Because current models are too effective

options.label: B
options.text: Because emergencies, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, have shown that they are essential

options.label: C
options.text: Because hospitals have too many ventilators

title: Why can't dogs eat chocolate?

multiple-choice.question: What molecule in chocolate makes it toxic to pets like dogs, cats, rats, and mice?
What type of molecule is theobromine classified as?
What is the effect of theobromine on the human heart?

options.label: A
options.text: It slows down the heart rate

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the heart pump faster

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the heart

options.label: D
options.text: It stops the heart from pumping

multiple-choice.question: Why are humans less susceptible to theobromine poisoning than pets?

options.label: C
options.text: Humans have a higher body weight

options.label: D
options.text: Humans have a lower body weight

multiple-choice.question: Why might humans have evolved to be better at digesting theobromine?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our ancestors ate a lot of meat

options.label: B
options.text: Because our ancestors ate a lot of plants

options.label: C
options.text: Because our ancestors drank a lot of coffee

options.label: D
options.text: Because our ancestors ate a lot of chocolate

multiple-choice.question: Why are cats less likely to get poisoned from chocolate?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they can taste sweet things

options.label: B
options.text: Because they can't taste sweet things

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are heavier than dogs

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are lighter than dogs

multiple-choice.question: How much dark chocolate would a medium-sized dog need to eat to get a lethal dose of theobromine?
What type of chocolate has less theobromine?
How much milk chocolate would a human need to eat to get a lethal dose of theobromine?
Why should you not share chocolate with your pets?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can be toxic to them
